results.title: Sea of stars
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Doris Unger
results.brief_description: A moon gazer rescues the stars that have been kidnapped by a mischievous man intent on melting them and turning them into gold.

results.title: Sea in the blood
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In Cyprus, folk history tales tell of children dying from anaemia. Village elders know that significant numbers of children have died and continue to die of a disease of the blood, called thalassemia. The video explains the incidence and treatment of thalassemia in villages of the Mediterranean. A doctor in the British Army, Colin Bate, gives accounts of the disease in Cyprus villages and specific cases are discussed. Techniques for the antenatal diagnosis of thalassemia are explained and the idea of genetic engineering is explored.

results.title: Sea Festivals of Hong Kong
results.creator_credit: J Murray, Hong Kong Film Unit and Ben R. Hart
results.brief_description: The sea between Hong Kong and neighbouring islands is the setting for many festivals and ceremonies in Southeast Asia. A beautifully photographed film on the junk and sampan dwellers, their life, fishing and in particular their colorful religious festivals.

results.title: Sea eagles
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, Film Australia and David E. Barrow
results.brief_description: A recruiting film for the Royal Australian Navy, showing life in Australia’s Fleet Air Arm. We see how living on an aircraft carrier is exciting and full of non-stop action. We also see how Australia’s Navy aviators fly helicopters for rescue and recovery, as well as attack, and the striking force of the fixed wing Skyhawk jets and the two-engined Tracker aircraft as they come and go from the deck of their seabound base.

results.title: Sea creatures
results.brief_description: An underwater look at the inhabitants of the Red Sea. These creatures appear to be from another world yet they are a very real part of the Sea’s ecosystem. Imaginative music and sound effects heighten the beautiful underwater photography. This film is a comment upon the fragile web of life. Film without narration.

results.title: Sculptured seal
results.brief_description: Follows the work of Tom Bass on the 70-foot copper relief mural at the entrance of the National Library, Canberra, a symbolic complex embodying traditional images of learning and cultural heritage. The sculptor explains his approach to the project as its development from sketches and models through fabrication and placing of the completed work is shown.

results.title: Sculpture of the Parthenon
results.creator_credit: Howard Tracy and Hugh Baddeley Productions
results.brief_description: Provides a comprehensive coverage of the sculpture of the Parthenon. In addition to the remains in Athens, the film covers the full scale replica of the Parthenon at Nashville, Tennessee; the model and exhibits in the Royal Ontario Museum of Toronto, Canada. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Sculpture of Ian Bow: man into metal
results.brief_description: Presents the major work by Australian sculptor Ian Bow: the bronze cycle “The Attitudes and Passions of Man”. Comprising 23 pieces of sculpture, the cycle aims to typify the depths and shallows of human experience. The first part of the film illustrates the whole process - two-dimensional studies, small models, full-size models, casting and finishing - by which such sculpture is realised. Narrated by Eric Westbrook.
